results.title: The Birth of Soviet cinema
results.creator_credit: Maxim Gorky Film Studio Moscow and Harold Mantell
results.brief_description: Examines the golden age of cinema in Russia in the 1920’s by presenting excerpts from masterworks of Eisenstein, Pudovkin and Dovzhenko by film critic Richard Schickel. Explains why the 1920’s was a productive time for cinema in general.

results.title: The Birth of New China = Kai Guo Da Dian
results.creator_credit: Changchun Film Studio, Li Qiankuan and Xiao Guiyun
results.brief_description:
This is a detailed retelling of the events leading up to and following the Communists’ triumph in the Chinese Civil War (1945-1949), from the perspective of the two leaders of the contending parties. Although there is a distinct agenda in the narrative, the film attempts to display an objective point of view, examining quite closely the human strengths and flaws of the leaders of both sides. While the film takes a distinct moral position, there is a distinct shift in narrative approach from films of the pre-Cultural Revolution period.

Jiang Kai-Shek, leader of the Kuomintang (Nationalist) party is shown to be a worthy adversary to Chairman Mao Zedong. The Nationalists have so far outgunned and outmanned the Communists. All the Reds have going for them is the support and respect of the common people, what Mao calls “the heart and soul of China”. Jiang ends up being defeated and flees to Taiwan, vowing to return and crush Mao.

On February 3, 1949, Communist army enters Beiping, where Mao gives his famous speech (the original footage is shown in part). Meanwhile, Jiang laments his defeat, explaining in hindsight how the Kuomintang overthrew itself. The sore point of the film for the Mainland Chinese is the so-called “stripping of wealth and treasures” from China, transporting them overseas to Taiwan. This was an epic operation, with shiploads of gold and cultural treasures being secretly transported to Taiwan over the final months of the war.
Celebrating the 40th Birthday of the People’s Republic of China (1949)
(3 stars: James Donald; June 10, 2011)

results.title: The Birth of Australia's golden age
results.brief_description: A history of the Australian gold rushes of the nineteenth century, which shows historical paintings and views of still extant gold mining towns. Demonstrates the various methods of extracting gold Narrated by Roger Climpson.

results.title: The Birth of a nation
results.creator_credit: D W Griffith Productions, D.W. Griffith and Frank Woods
results.brief_description:
This epic Civil War drama portrays life in the South during and after the Civil War. The film derives its emotional power from its moving constantly from the large drama to intimate human stories, in particular the war’s effects on a Northern family (the Stonemans) and its Southern counterpart (the Camerons). It is one of the most influential films in the history of the cinema and, because of its racism, one of the most controversial. Also available on 35mm and VHS. Other versions also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producer, director, D.W. Griffith ; writers, D.W. Griffith, Frank E. Woods ; photography, G.W. Bitzer.
Cast: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh, Henry Walthall, Ralph Lewis.

results.title: The Birth of a brain : ten billion galaxies (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Levant, CRM/McGraw-Hill Films and Claude Edelman
results.brief_description: Looks at the development of the human brain from embryo stage through to the first years of life. Computer graphics, sonography and film of living nerve cells show the process and progress of development at different stages. This is a version of a French documentary, ‘Naissance du cerveau : dix milliards de galaxies’ with a dubbed American commentary.

results.title: The Birders
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Films (Australia), Broken Hill Proprietary Company, John Richardson and David Morgan
results.brief_description: Winner of the 1976 Australian National Travel Association Jedda Award at the Australian Film Awards. The mutton bird industry of the Furneaux Islands (Cape Barren Island and Flinders Island) in Bass Strait is a little known and historic primary industry started by sealers more than 150 years ago. The film records the rugged life style of the small band of people involved in Mutton birding. Narrated by Ross Thompson and photographed by Kevin Anderson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Bird who is a clown
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Walker
results.brief_description: Introduces the island Daphne Major of the Galapagos Islands which is a small island and nesting ground for hundrreds of Blue-footed Booby birds. Emphasises the mating and upbringing of the young in order to illustrate the development of the Booby and to reveal its behaviour patterns. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Bird fancier = L'Homme aux oiseaux
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover, Bernard Devlin and Jean Palardy
results.brief_description: Staged in old Quebec City, this film is about a rebel against the time-clock, whose hobby was snaring birds but whose dream was to escape the bonds of domesticity. A kindly satire of the dreamer in every man, the film is also a memorable portrait of Quebec, the “Grande Dame” of Canadian cities. With English subtitles. Cast includes Maurice Beaupre, Rene Constantineau, Camille Fournier, Roger Lebel, Annette Leclerc. Written by Roger Lemelin. Photography by Grant McLean. Edited by Douglas Tunstell. Music by Maurice Blackburn. Sound by Joseph Champagne.

results.title: The Biosphere
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells, Peter Katadotis, Colin Low and William Pettigrew
results.brief_description: The McKenzie and Amazon Valleys are 10,000 kilometres distant from one another and are certainly distinct ecologically. Yet in a subtle sense they are collaborating elements within the biosphere - the Earth’s thin layer of living matter. This film examines two of the myriad river ecosystems and shows how they are linked within the biosphere.
